Article.ArticleTitle: Quantifying wintertime O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>x</sub> formation with relevance vector machines.

AbstractText: This paper uses a machine learning model called a relevance vector machine (RVM) to quantify ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) and nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>) formation under wintertime conditions. Field study measurements were based on previous work described by Olson et al. (2019), where continuous measurements were reported from a wintertime field study in Utah. RVMs were formulated using either O<sub>3</sub> or nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) as the output variable. Values of the correlation coefficient (r<sup>2</sup>) between predicted and measured concentrations were 0.944 for O<sub>3</sub> and 0.931 for NO<sub>2</sub>. RVMs are constructed from the observed measurements and result in sparse model formulations, meaning that only a subset of the data is used to approximate the entire dataset. For this study, the RVM with O<sub>3</sub> as the output variable used only 20% of the measurement data while the RVM with NO<sub>2</sub> used 16%. RVMs were then used as a predictive model to assess the importance of individual precursors. Using O<sub>3</sub> as the output variable, increases in three species resulted in increased O<sub>3</sub> concentrations: hydrogen peroxide (H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>), dinitrogen pentoxide (N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>), and molecular chlorine (Cl<sub>2</sub>). For the two termination products measured during the study, nitric acid (HNO<sub>3</sub>) and formic acid (CH<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>), no change in O<sub>3</sub> concentration was observed. Using NO<sub>2</sub> as the output variable, only increases in N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> resulted in increased NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations.
